plotText.plainText: A story of seven individuals caught up in a fragment of time - a microcosm where every event has a ripple effect on the lives of each of the protagonists. What holds them together is that they each, in their own way, are searching for acceptance - to be 'someone' in a world that is all too happy to pass them by and write them off as the losers. Yes they all have a past, a present and at least some hope for the future - which they will tell you about during the course of the evening. Perhaps the tragedy is that no matter what happens to these seven, time will flow on regardless and untouched by actualities - and that, in the end, the momentous events recorded here will eventually spread out and be forgotten in the pool of time. Spend a little time with our seven friends - Steve, Jay, Dips, Mary, Shaun, Dean and Tony. Listen to their stories and make up your own minds!"

plotText.plainText: Maine people of diverse ages, cultures and gender identities share their compelling experiences and wisdom addressing climate injustices in Maine and beyond. Some challenge institutions and their own communities to say "no" to fossil fuels expansion. Some embrace their ancestors' and present-day struggles for land and water sovereignty. Some are creating a model for fossil-fuel free living. And some risked arrest in solidarity with frontline communities in the southwest and Alberta, Canada, who are experiencing the pain of environmental and social injustices. What are the seeds for their activism? Where do they find courage, hope and support to continue to work on the global crisis of climate change? What can we learn from their experiences and incorporate into our own lives?

plotText.plainText: Religion came into being to build a harmonious society. Ancient Hindu religion, the oldest of all is not initiated by one person but implored a way of life exploring betterment of the community. The scriptures, mantr(the chants) & rituals have a strong scientific base, meaning & understanding of which is losing its luster over the years. Today's youth going global is confused about this basic faith, God is not an entity but the positive energy with'in' & demon is the negative energy with'out'. Hindu religion is based on 5 basic natural energies, Sun, wind, rain, earth & space of which every living being is made of. Chaos & confusion in the minds of Today's youth devoid him of the concrete strength of life, This film creates a story interwoven with such simple day to day life characters which try to simplify the complexities of religion. Religion if understood in right perspective develops the individual, mass & societal mind simultaneously, but that's what is lost as it is being superficially politicized-used for selfish gains. No religion can ever preach destruction of mankind... it's the no or low understanding of the executors & followers who see the Religion with incorrect perspective. Religion initiates such strength in every single human outreaching the entire society building plane harmony. From with'in' to with'out' is its journey. So let today's youth understand clearly the simplicity of it & how it binds each one of us to have that collective strength.

What does it mean to live in a neighborhood? What does the place where you live mean to you? Who lives next-door? In the summer of 2017, 140 people who live on and around Rosa-Luxemburg Platz in Berlin's 'Mitte' district were interviewed. These conversations were turned into a series of short films that provide personal insights into diverse lives. Behind each door there's a different story: long-standing Mitte dwellers, founders of start-ups, centenarians, globetrotters, those pining for the old East Germany, and students. There are people who have lived here for two months or sixty years; people who grew up in what used to be East or West Germany, in Latin America, Russia, or former Yugoslavia. A neighborhood full of diversity and contradictions. Some call it their home, others just the place they live, while still others think of it as a real neighborhood or 'kiez'. And yet, memories and emotions associated with this place connect them all as neighbors. For the premiere at the International Film Festival Berlin 2018, the spectators were led through three private living rooms of interview partners by a guide. Two episodes were shown in each apartment. The viewers were invited to continue the discussions initiated in the films with the residents before moving on to the next living room.

This documentary provides a detailed behind-the-scenes look at the production of fantasy series called Chronicles of Alt Earth, focusing on collaboration and creativity of the crew members, led by director Joshua Michael at Selway Studios. The team is dedicated to creating an immersive experience, drawing inspiration from iconic franchises like Star Wars and Marvel films. Utilizing visual effects technology on a limited budget, they craft a visually stunning world and release episodic content for flexibility in production and financing. One specific character, Wreath, is highlighted as a dream role for an actress, blending elements of Star Wars, magic, and warrior tribes. The character's internal struggles and journey of balancing power and integrity resonate with the actress, who finds parallels to real-life dynamics and personal growth. The collaborative atmosphere on set enhances the storytelling, with a focus on character development and narrative depth, exploring themes of love, loyalty, and the interplay of light and darkness. The detailed discussion also delves into another character, Carson, shedding light on motivations, struggles, and themes such as prejudice and personal growth within a fantastical setting. The actress's insights reveal the depth of storytelling and character dynamics, adding layers to the narrative through contrasting elements like youthful exuberance and ancient wisdom. The documentary offers a glimpse into the world-building process, the challenges of portraying magical abilities, and the collaborative efforts that contribute to a compelling story. Overall, the transcript captures the passion, dedication, and camaraderie of the production team as they bring the fantasy world of Chronicles of Alt Earth to life. Through the lens of the actress and her experiences portraying characters like Wreath and Carson, viewers gain a deeper understanding of the themes of power, morality, and personal growth that drive the narrative forward. The blend of creativity, technical expertise, and collaborative spirit shines through, offering a behind-the-scenes peek into the magic of creating an immersive fantasy series.

Omar Galliani' the great artist from Emilia tells about his art and sources of inspiration, his pictorial and drawing techniques (mainly the artist draws with graphite and charcoal very large poplar wood surfaces), passing reviewing his latest exhibitions, at CAMeC della Spezia, at Civic Museums of Reggio Emilia, until the exhibition 'Around Caravaggio' at Galleries of Italy-Piazza Scala in Milan, where he made three great works inspired by the 'Martyrdom of Sant' Orsola' by Caravaggio. During the trip we will see the big 'Siderea' curtain of the Valli theater in Reggio Emilia, his home-studio, we will meet his wife Laura Intilia and his son Michelangelo, both sculptors; we will hear about the dozens of exhibitions he has done in China; we will see it in the large studio of Montecchio Emilia, with two students from Lyceum and Academy, while restoring a large painting, 'Mantra'. We will also know the students of the Accademia di Brera where the artist has been teaching the Painting Course for years; we will go along the river Enza to see the rows of poplars that Omar uses for his works, we will also see the channel of the Incoronata, built by Leonardo for the Sforza, now dried up, where on the bottom Omar has deliberately deposited three tables for months, to transform themselves under the effect of rain. We will know the artist and the man Omar Galliani, and his stylistic and expressive coherence and morality.

plotText.plainText: The spirit of Giorgio Fieschi is found in the enthusiasm of his stories, but also - by extension - in the expressions of the multitude of great music artists interviewed during a long career as a journalist. And in having been able to be, in a completely natural way, an "equal degree" of many characters who have written the history of Italian and world music: equal degree because a profound connoisseur and visceral lover of music, exactly like the artists they created music, and gave it to the fans, on the other side of the fence. "Everything in my life - Giorgio likes to say - ends up in music". The television and radio archives are dotted with gems that refer to this rare privileged relationship that Fieschi has always been able to create with the great masters of the musical world, since the 70s and up to the present day. Many interviews (or should we call them chats between friends?). A great passion, his, a passion that he rode until music and his encounters became the center of a career that began as a news reporter. A passion that over the years has allowed him to meet great people and cultivate friendships and acquaintances, such as the one with Mal of the Primitives, the singer consecrated by the legendary Piper club and, much later, by "Furia" - that theme song for a children's TV show which even today many children hum.

titleText.text: East Africa - Arcadia World Cosmos Global Travel Films

originalTitleText.text: East Africa - Arcadia World Cosmos Global Travel Films

plotText.plainText: East Africa is one of the most beautiful and diverse landscapes in the world and its magnificent wilderness and fascinating wildlife is one of the few remaining unspoiled regions on earth. Lake Naivasha is the ideal habitat for both the rare Fish Eagle and African Eagle, thus it is a perfect location from which to observe these fascinating birds. Due to its rich variety of wildlife and the spectacular beauty of its landscape, Kenya is one of Africa's most popular safari destinations. The Massai Mara National Park is located around six hours from Nairobi and is one of the country's most extraordinary game reserves. Its name indicates the presence of one of Africa's most colorful tribes, the Massai. The Amboseli National Park also contains many of East Africa's most important landscapes and represents the magnificence of the African flora and fauna that grows in this relatively small, protected area. The local wildlife stays at a safe distance from the geysers of Lake Bogoria, as the steaming hot springs can prove fatal for the flamingos and other water birds that live there. Nevertheless, quite often, the bones of dead animals can be seen close to the geysers as some venture too close and are killed by the hot steam. At an altitude of nearly 6,000 meters, Mount Kilimanjaro is the highest mountain on the African continent. For most of the time, its summit is covered by a dense ring of cloud that gives the mountain an air of mystique. There are few other places on earth that offer the huge variety of nature as does the legendary east of the African continent. A magical destination and a wild natural paradise that is second to none.

In Soando, a small island in Wando, the legacy of fighting against the Japanese and the sadness of the Korean war coexist. Just before the 1990s, the anti-Japanese activity was made known to the world, and the sacrifices made during the Korean War have been somewhat consoled through the truth and reconciliation committee project, but is there no more suppression? El Immigrant (2015) is a 46-minute experimental documentary film that explores the experiences of visible minority immigrants in Canada upon their arrival and their (in)ability to integrate into society. The film combines autobiography with field interviews, screen recordings, and found footage (advertisements, old documentaries, YouTube how-to videos, etc.) to create what the author calls a 'constructed dialogue': a technique of creating a conversational dialogue between people who would probably never meet or converse; the author, however, through the power of montage, can introduce them to each other. The film uncovers themes of identity and how it relates to profession, the politics of (in)visibility, multiculturalism, racism, and 'linguistic terrorism'. The film is meant to be digressive, associative, and self-reflexive - unconventional qualities that would make the viewer always alert and uncomfortable (and thus questioning why they are feeling so).

The film is a poetic testimony of the personal impacts of being removed from ones home and isolated in the residential school system. The gathering was organized by the Legacy of Hope Foundation in collaboration with the Nunatsiavut Government.

Traveling through the life and work of the painter Luis Quintanilla Isasi, with his great quantity of experiences and his presence in singular moments of our recent history, "The Other Guernicas" deals with the enormous loss that the exodus of the most significant thing of one of our intellectuals meant for the culture of our country, as a fatal consequence of the Civil War and the later Dictatorship.

The symbolism that encloses the gestation and the vicissitude lived by the fresco paintings (Los Frescos, "Ama la paz, odia la guerra", currently exhibited in the Paraninfo of the University of Cantabria) that Luis Quintanilla elaborated by commission of the Government of the Republic for the Pavilion of Spain in the Universal Exhibition of New York in 1939, and that were disappeared from 1940 to 1990, places them as a fundamental narrative axis of the history that develops this work.

Santiago Carrillo, Alfonso Guerra, Almudena Grandes, Gabriel Jackson... are some of the more than twenty testimonies of the documentary "Los Otros Guernicas", but the great star of the collaborators is, without a doubt, the brilliant New York director and actor Woody Allen.

These testimonies allow us to delimit how was the life of this brilliant artist, how was his life and his works, to go rescuing little by little his known works and the lost ones. With the passage of time some of this artist's works were forgotten, but thanks to this documentary an unknown information is rescued that will submerge the spectator in its recovery.

plotText.plainText: A collaborative video and activism project between long-time community filmmaker Rebecca Garrett and Sanctuary, a church community drop-in, evolves into an unflinching documentary immersion into the world of police and security guard violence against people who are poor, homeless, and racialized in Toronto. 'We have to stop calling the police,' says activist Anna Willats. And the message resonates in dozens of stories collected by street pastor Doug Johnson Hatlem. Stunning testimony, images, and commentary are woven together with unique video of police assaults and previously unreleased footage from inside the 2010 G20 detention centre. Conflict erupts over nonviolent responses to overwhelming police impunity. Meanwhile, the increasing militarization of public spaces forces us all to ask: What World Do You Live In?

The big night is here. From the fresh corsages and hairdos to the sweaty last dance and the morning after, The Prom tracks a group of students from Montreal's FACE High School, charting 24 hours of a great adolescent ritual. Observant and affectionate, this film captures a wealth of telling detail. The teary conversations with parents over morning coffee--Mon choux. You've grown up so fast. The long hours at the beauty salon--Do I need more mascara? The preparations for the after-grad booze-up--Drinking is the heart and soul of my social life. The film bops along, infected by all those raging teenage hormones, against a hip soundtrack that combines Montreal acts like Bran Van 3000 with the lush sentiment of Louis Armstrong. Finally, the cameras capture the bittersweet dawn on Mount Royal as the group disperses. Part Cinderella, part American Graffiti, with a dash of Saturday Night Fever, The Prom is smart, touching and funny--a movie snapshot that appeals to the teenager in everyone.

titleText.text: Z Gliwic do Paryza. Wojtek Pszoniak

originalTitleText.text: Z Gliwic do Paryza. Wojtek Pszoniak

plotText.plainText: A fictionalized documentary about the artistic path of Wojciech Pszoniak. The journey through the life of one of the most outstanding Polish actors begins with the hero of the film himself, standing by the radio station tower in Gliwice, where he was raised and grew up. The tall structure always reminded him of the Eiffel Tower, but at that time he could not have known that he would spend his adult life in Paris. The camera moves from Gliwice to the city on the Seine, where the actor settled permanently in the 1980s. We meet him in the famous Montparnasse, a favorite place in Paris not only of our famous compatriot. The greatest personalities from the world of art frequented the nearby bistro, including: Picasso, Matisse, Hemingway, Scott Fitzgerald and actors Claude Brasseur and Michele Piccoli, Wojciech Pszoniak also comes here. The restaurant is located near the theater where he performed. He recalls the play "The Shop on the Street Corner", performed for two years to a full audience, in which he and his French colleagues played as many as 484 times.

Shot in Paris, Death Valley, and the Nevada nuclear test site, this film essay examines the complex historical relationship between photography, cinema and science. The film explores the impact of chrono-photographic experiments of Irish-born Lucien Bull (1876 - 1972) on the developments of image-capture aesthetics and science throughout the 20th century, showing how technologies of vision were aggressively instrumentalised by the military-industrial complex, particularly by the nuclear testing industry. Using rarely-seen nuclear test footage alongside more poetic images and new film from the nuclear test site in Nevada, I See A Darkness questions cinema's relationship with the material world, with contributions from leading philosophers and writers.

This film focuses on the music, lives, and dreams of the troubadours who make their living playing along Havana, Cuba's Malecon seawall. The Malecon, a 5-km, 3-ft high seawall that runs along the shores of Havana, serves as the inspiration and backdrop for the film and accompanying album. Because of the economic situation in Cuba where monthly salaries average around $20, few can afford to go to clubs and restaurants. Instead, thousands come together along this 5-km stretch to socialize, drink Cuba Libres, sell goods, and even engage in illegal activities. The film captures the social, political, and personal context from which this music arises giving a unique and unfettered view of Cuba.

plotText.plainText: A portrait of Chinese conductor Muhai Tang's extraordinary life. Born in 1949, the founding year of the People's Republic of China, and raised during the Cultural Revolution, it seemed as if he would have to abandon his dream of a career in music. However, his talent, perseverance and the support of Herbert von Karajan ultimately brought him to the world's concert halls. Today, Muhai Tang is a global nomad. A wanderer between the worlds which he unites with music. His personal history, interspersed with historical caesurae, is typical for Chinese of his generation. He gained access to western culture early on through music. Muhai Tang's life and work are exemplary of a changing China and the enrichment of the world by an artist between East and West.

Despite the American and European sanctions imposed on the Syrian regime, and its men; the regime was able to run and maintain its financial networks ensuring that its economy remained intact throughout the process. This investigative documentary utilises official documents, and the testimonies of prominent Syrian figures to explain the methods used to circumvent the imposed sanctions revealing the names of influential personalities, and the size of their wealth and operations. The film also highlights the reasons for the disposal of Rami Makhlouf, one of the most prominent pillars of the Syrian regime's network, while exploring the reasons for his ongoing dispute between with Asma al-Assad; the first lady of Syria.

They flee together but are captured and held with other prisoners of the gang. Dubbed "The People's Poet" by fellow poets, he won the Governor General's Literary Award in 1975. Burned out by personal crises, Acorn moved back to Charlottetown in 1981. This film, brings out Acorn's wit, love of nature, unorthodox political views, and sometimes infuriating personal contradictions.

With the death of Queen Elizabeth II, let's take a look back at coronations in recent history.

In quantum physics, if two particles interact in a certain way and then become separated, regardless how distant they are from each other they will share a state called quantum entanglement. This documentary intertwines four interviews collected in Cali, Colombia. A tailor, a puppeteer, a parapsychologist and a physicist narrate certain episodes occurred in the city: the disappearance of a cow; the death on stage of a puppet character; a paradox in quantum mechanics; and the fall of a bus into a river due to a lion on the road. A latent entanglement between elements of the stories emerges, outlining a hypothesis of action at a distance.

plotText.plainText: Anna, a young shop girl, is urged by her rather disreputable stepmother, Mrs. Biddle, not to be so particular, to liven up and get presents and favors from rich young fellows. Lena Schmidt, a co-worker at the store, "stands in" with the manager and lies to her mother about the jewels and dresses. Lena's affair is cut short when the proprietors find her telling the manager about her delicate condition. She believes Anna has told on her and threatens revenge for her discharge. Anna attracts the attention of John Stevens, a salesman, who believes her to be like Lena, but when he attempts advances after a dinner, he finds out his mistake. His respect is aroused and he begs Anna to marry him. For a while the young couple are happy, but Mrs. Biddle's nagging gradually gets on John's nerves and he begins to seek amusement outside of his home. Mrs. Biddle tells Anna she is a fool to stand for this treatment; John is having a good time, why doesn't she go out and enjoy herself. Lena, who still harbors a resentment against Anna, plays on the girl's loneliness when she learns from Mrs. Biddle of the conditions in Anna's home. After long miserable waiting for John's homecoming, Anna decides one night to stand it no longer and accepts Lena's invitation to a party. Arrived at Lena's apartment she is somewhat surprised at the people she meets there, and later in the night, when the men arrived to carouse and make free with the girls, she awakes to a full realization of the nature of the party she is attending. She tries to get away, to flee from the repellent advances of the "Deacon," one of the guests, but Lena tells her there is no escape. As the Deacon seizes Anna in his arms the door bursts open and Dr. Goode enters; he had been a sweetheart of Anna's before her marriage and had never ceased to care for her. He had learned of her presence at the party and had determined to ascertain the reason fro it and to save her if possible. Anna gladly goes with him from the place. At home John is watching over Nanny, the little neglected daughter of the unhappy couple. Nanny is ill and is crying for her mother. He is overjoyed when Dr. Goode leads Anna in. Explanations and reconciliation follow and over their baby's bed they plan for a new and better life.

"Shiva's daughter" A Movie An English movie.

Background of the story.

This is an emotional love story which ends in tragedy. Both Parents oppose to their children's loving relationship because they are of different communities from Sri Lanka known as the Tamils and the Sinhalese. This story is period based, which happens within six months in London during the peak of the war of Sri Lanka in 2009.

Characters of the film.

Danny is a Sri-Lankan Sinhalese by birth who is in his mid-thirties. He is a Doctoral student reading PHD finals in International relations specializing in "Conflict resolution". Also, Danny is a pacifist who is not interested in Governmental politics in Sri Lanka. Danny is been adopted in London by his Uncles Joy since Danny's mum passed away in Sri Lanka. Joy is Sarath's wife's brother. Joy too has a brother in London called Raj who is another Uncle for Danny. However, all Danny's expenses and the cost of his private education in London are being funded by his biological father Sarath. Sarath is rich and also a Deputy Foreign Minister of the Government of Sri Lanka.

Dammi is a Sri-Lankan Tamil born in Paris who is now in her early thirties. She reads LLB finals in Middlesex University. Dammi is the only daughter of Shiva who is an educated Tamil Gentleman. Shiva is a strong activist in human rights and a forerunner among the Tamil protesters in London whose aim is to stop the war in Sri Lanka to save thousands of Tamils trapped in the war zone. Shiva and his daughter Dammi live in London, having been the asylum seekers in Paris on the basis that they were the victims of the communal riot in 1983 in the Capital City of Sri Lanka where Shiva lost his only son to the rioting mob.

Synopsis.

The movie commences by showing how the Tamils were protesting in London against the war and it ends on the day the war ends while the "Tamil Rebel Leader" is finally killed. However, the Civil war is not the theme of the movie but a love story is. Danny is a Sinhalese and Dammi is a Tamil. They meet each other at the University while Danny visits to Lecturer law students in " Conflict Resolution".

Danny's biological father is Sarath who is the Deputy Foreign Minister in Sri Lankan government. He is arrives in the UK on a mission to seek support from the United kingdom for their war against Tamil rebels in Sri Lanka. However his only ambition and dream in his life is to see his son Danny returns home after his PHD to start his career in politics in Sri Lanak. However, Danny being a pacifist, flatly refuses his dad's request to return home because (A) he has no interest in Governmental Politics in Sri Lankan. (B) He is in love with Dammi and he wants to marry her. This infuriates his father Sarath. Sarath feels himself being betrayed by his son Danny.

Shiva too talks to Dammi several times to give up his relationship with Danny and Dammi though loves her dad very much, refuses his request.

Tamils are intensifying their protests in thousands on the streets of London and camping in Parliament square. Shiva is spear-heading the organizations. Hunger strikes and protest marches against the war are undertaken worldwide. MPs are raising the issues in the British Parliament. Indian actors are holding meetings and hunger strikes in South India. David Multiband (Foreign Minister) travels to Sri Lanka to initiate ceasefire.

Shiva is having meetings with his colleagues about their next strategy on protests and lobbying the parliamentarians in London. Police have meetings with the organizers so to conduct the protest marches abiding British Law.

Sarath, having failed to convince Danny to breakup with Dammi, requests his in Laws Joy and Raj to find out the details of Dammi and her family before he leaves London to Geneva.

Upon knowing that Dammi's dad Shiva too is not in favor of Dammi's relationship with Danny he requests Joy and Raj to arrange a meeting with Dammi's dad Shiva and consequently Sarath , Joy, and Raj meet Shiva.

However, during the meeting Shiva recognizes Sarath because there were bad memories between them when they were contemporaries in those days in Sri Lanka. Shiva recalls the events and abuses Sarath for what he had done to him and I and storms out of the meeting.

Both Danny and Dammi continue relationship.

Dummy and Danny gets attacked by the Tamil vigilantes at the protest march and Dammi receives the worse of it. Her kidneys are damaged and needs transplantation. Since NHS can't provide the operation because of shortage of donors, the specialists suggest that it can be done legally in Apollo in Madras. The cost is estimated to be £75L.

However a dilemma exists. Shiva knows that he wouldn't get his Indian Visa to Join his daughter and Danny has no money either to take Dammi to India for transplantation.

The news is flashing nationwide on Radios, TVs and newspapers that NHS is postponing serious operations for lack of funds and because of this some patients of serious illnesses are at risk of dying.

Danni applies for bank loans but the Bank rejects his applications for lack of collateral and credit rating. Joy volunteers to unlock money from his house to pay the cost.

Shiva is now swallowing his pride and meets Sarath to help him to get his Visa because Sarath knows higher places at the Indian Embassy. Sarath agrees with Shiva that he will get the Visa to on condition that Shiva helps his son to return to Sri Lanka and Shiva agrees to it.

Danny too approaches Sarath for money and Sarath grips Danny to a deal that he will return home to enter politics after the operation and Danny agrees to it under his circumstances. Sarath now celebrates within himself that he finally got his son to do what he always wanted.

However, in spite of all arrangements are been made for Dammi to be flown to India, she dies on the last day while the war ends where tens and thousands of Civilians too are killed. It is this genocide that Shiva wanted to stop but on the last day he loses his daughter and loses the people too.

The movie ends.
